author: @polyroguegames5820
text: Huh. This doesn't work nearly as well for me, though I think it's down to the lane finder more than anything. Odd, since I used your code.  Also, I'm super confused! I can't figure out why you should go left when both m's are negative and vice versa! Surely, if both slopes are negative, i.e. going from the bottom right to the top left, it means it can't see the middle of  the road and so we're too far right, and should go left, no? And so if both are positive, we should go right?  Thank you!  EDIT: Never mind! So it was two things. One was that the values for the line threshold either are changed off cam or I just missed them, and the other is that the road really matters. I found a stretch after loads of searching that had the double yellow solid line and it worked waaaaay better than on the road I was trying. Thanks again!

author: @AbeDillon
text: Make it slow a little every time it has to turn. Then add "momentum" so that if it keeps turning the same direction, it turns a little harder and slows a little more each time.  Edit: You'd want the "momentum" to decay towards zero over a period of a few seconds because, otherwise, when it completes a left turn, it will be highly biased to turn more left than right.

author: @OOJokerOO1991
text: I just stumbled upon this video/series and I have no idea if you already fixed the problem with your vehicle turning to slow. Here is my idea: if m1 < 0 and m2 < 0 : if prev_move = right() : hardright() else: right() elif m1 > 0 and m2 > 0 : if prev_move = left() : hardleft() else: left() else: straight()  hardright() (or hardleft) are nearly the same as right() (or left) just without the release (D) (or release (A)). Maybe you need to tweak it so the "hard"-variant gets triggered after the third, forth etc time going in one direction.  I hope you get what I'm trying to say xD  p.s.: great series! I'm going to watch the other parts now :D p.p.s: I've no idea how python works so I just guessed you could stack if functions in one another.

author: @KonstantinUb
text: 5:47 That's a terrible way to count down from 4. You should never turn a range into a list just to reverse it—instead, make a range that counts down from the get-go: for i in range(4, 0, -1): 　print(i)  Or do it the more Pythonic way (read PEP 322 for more details): for i in reversed(range(4)): 　print(i+1)  (I personally prefer the former.)

author: @blogspoto
text: You could try to find some coordinates from the slopes(coordinates of points that are on the slope),and then make up the point that is half of the line between the two slopes(using math formulas,that point's x value is the sum of the 2 points x coordinates divided by 2,and the y value is the sum of the 2 points y coordinates divided by 2) and that would be the center of the lane.With that,you can have it always refer to the middle of the road and then check if it is on the right of the center,go left ,elif is it on the left,go right and else go straight.This would solve the going out of the road problem,and with a bit of smoothing on the definitions of left,right and straight,you can get a nice turn.And for the speed problem,you can integrate a timer in the project,a timer on how long has the car moved straight.With a bit of testing,you can find out how much it will take the car to get to a certain speed ,and when your timer is kinda close to that value,you slow the car down.

author: @fafaschiavo2
text: Nice series! I noticed that you are using only the slopes’ signs as a criteria for turning.  But if we think about the way we drive in real life, when you are driving faster you need to anticipate turns that are far from your current position. I noticed the image processing function only perceives both lines with the same sign when you are already too close from the extreme of the road.  One simple solution would be to analyze the difference between the slopes absolute values (ignoring their signs), if the difference is bigger than an acceptable value you start turning already. I noticed that would probably save your driver in 11’10’’, and I think it would work in other moments as well.  This could be done easily by simply adding another condition to your if…elif…else statement. Something like this:   acceptable_diff = 1 #i am guessing this blindly, adjust this accordingly slope_diff = abs(m1)-abs(m2)  if (m1 < 0 and m2 < 0) or (abs(slope_diff) > acceptable_diff and slope_diff > 0):  right() elif (m1 > 0  and m2 > 0) or (abs(slope_diff) > acceptable_diff and slope_diff < 0):  left() else:  straight()   I just typed this here (not the best text editor though hahahaha), but i think you got the idea.  Anyway congrats for the results! And please continue with the awesome videos!

author: @a_resident7363
text: Hey man. Great video and really cool project. If you want to get better handling from your AI, it can be solved with a simple geometric model and some basic PID control. Once you can define obstacles on the road (other cars, pedestrians if you are feeling particularly ethical), you could also avoid hitting those using the same controller. You'll be fucked once you are first in line in a traffic light, but anyways I think it might be helpful. I've got a ton of material and articles on the subject if you're interested, let me know.  Good luck!

author: @liammacconn2744
text: I have wanted to do something like this ever since I first played GTA Vice City back in 2002, but never found the time to learn python nor someone to guide me until you started posting videos. Thank you! I've been having a lot of fun with Python this year.  1) You grayscale the image to threshold, which means you lose the difference between a white line and a yellow line. In this situation, keeping the double yellow line to the left and the white line to the right might work better. 2) Removing traffic might help. On GTA San Andreas and earlier there were codes to do that, but GTA IV and GTA V require modding to do that. 3) I was thinking about how a human would do this - we estimate our speed and position and make a mental map of our surroundings (as well as what is permenant like roads and what is movable like other cars). Is there a way for a (separate) process to use the captured images to build a 2D or 3D map? 3a) If so, can that process use the map and prediction models to guess at what actions will be necessary? Kinda like how it takes a human 2 seconds to move from gas to brake, but can predict well enough (sometimes) to _appear_ to make decisions in a fraction of a second.

author: @PeterSeres
text: Awesome project! However I think measuring your speed is essential for any self driving algorithm. Especially if you wanna go as fast as you can.  If you wanna keep it simple it  might be possible to approximate your speed using the history of left, right and straight decisions. You can look up or manually see how much acceleration a W   produces (I assume it's constant for a scooter) and you can also measure manually the deceleration of the scooter in idle mode. Since you know how much time every loop takes, you can always just say V += dv *dt and keep this going until you completly stop. It's a rough estimate but it's not graphical and at least the AI will know if it's going slow or fast.

author: @harley4007
text: When the slope of a line (lane) is too great, then make it so that the key is held down rather than releasing it very fast and pressing it down again. Also, release W while doing making these sharp turns. If a line is perpendicular to you, then you may want to slow down. I don't know python, but by watching, it seems that you could do something simpler. However, I believe slopes are everything in this, so use them to predict where a turn might occur as well. Since computers can process information extremely fast, use that to your advantage and create a whole bunch of different circumstances with turns and objects on the roads, and what the car should do when it goes off the road.   Oh yeah—note that it is important that when you turn, you must not only turn (press A) but also press W. this will prevent you from getting stuck.   As you program, think of a simple solution. There is always a more efficient way of doing things.
